name: Multisystemic Therapy (MST) for Families
summary: An intensive, evidence-based, home- and community-based intervention designed to address serious behavioral, emotional, and criminal problems in adolescents by targeting the multiple systems influencing their lives.
description: Multisystemic Therapy (MST) for Families is an intensive, family- and community-based treatment that addresses the serious clinical, social, and behavioral challenges of adolescents at risk for out-of-home placement due to delinquency, conduct disorder, substance use, or other severe behavioral problems. MST integrates cognitive-behavioral, family systems, and ecological approaches, working with caregivers, schools, peers, and community systems to build sustainable support. Treatment is delivered in the home, is highly individualized, and emphasizes empowering parents to manage their child’s behavior effectively while reducing reliance on formal systems.

contraindications: Adolescents with severe psychosis or acute psychiatric crises requiring hospitalization
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and effective; requires intensive family engagement and trained providers.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: High—multiple RCTs and meta-analyses; endorsed by Blueprints for Healthy Youth Development and SAMHSA.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Well-established in the U.S. and internationally; strong evidence for reducing recidivism and improving family functioning.

sections.text: MST is grounded in ecological systems theory and targets the multiple systems influencing adolescent behavior, including family, peers, school, and community. Therapists work directly with families to empower caregivers, improve parenting practices, reduce negative peer associations, strengthen prosocial connections, and coordinate with schools and community supports. The model emphasizes accountability, skill-building, and sustainable family-led solutions.

sections.preparation: Assessment of youth, family, and systemic risk factors; treatment planning tailored to specific family dynamics and contexts.
procedure: Home-based sessions with parents and adolescents several times per week.
Collaboration with schools, juvenile justice, and community agencies.
Implementation of CBT-based strategies, parent training, and systemic interventions.
sections.frequency: Multiple sessions per week, adjusted to family needs.
sections.duration: 3–5 months typical, may extend depending on severity and response.
sections.total_treatment_time: Intensive, short-term model with high therapist involvement.

sections.pre_session: Review of goals, progress, and family environment updates.
sections.treatment_phase: Direct work with family members, skill-building, crisis management.
sections.post_session: Homework assignments, monitoring, and coordination with external systems.

absolute: Immediate danger to self or others requiring inpatient care
relative: Unstable home environment with no caregiver involvement

ideal_candidates: Adolescents with chronic delinquency or substance use
Families with high conflict or instability
Youth at risk for incarceration or residential placement

practitioner: Licensed therapists trained in MST protocols

studies: Henggeler, S. W. et al. (1998). Multisystemic treatment of antisocial behavior in children and adolescents.
Meta-analyses show reductions in recidivism, substance use, and family conflict.
sections.limitations: Requires high family participation; resource-intensive; not suitable for youth needing inpatient psychiatric care.

sections.insurance_coverage: Often funded through Medicaid, juvenile justice, or child welfare programs
sections.cost_effectiveness: Cost-effective alternative to incarceration or residential treatment

sections.children: Not typically used for young children; designed for adolescents.

items: MST is an evidence-based alternative to incarceration and residential placement.
Therapists maintain low caseloads for intensive family engagement.

items.label: Henggeler, S. W. et al. (1998). Multisystemic Treatment of Antisocial Behavior in Children and Adolescents.
